questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of numbness and burning sensation in his legs. He also reports that his stools have been drier and harder than usual. He has non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Two weeks ago, he completed his last chemotherapy cycle with prednisone, vincristine, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased muscle strength in the distal muscles of the lower extremities. Ankle reflex is 1+ bilaterally and knee reflex is 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, vibration, and position is decreased over the lower extremities. Serum glucose, creatinine, and electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vincristine is an antineoplastic drug that is used for the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Its use is limited by neurotoxicity that manifests within 4–5 weeks of initiating therapy. Vincristine usually causes a mixed symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy predominantly affecting the distal lower extremities. Early symptoms include numbness and tingling, which are accompanied by decreased deep tendon reflexes. Over time, symptoms progress to muscle weakness. Patients with neuropathy due to vincristine may have dysautonomic features, particularly constipation due to decreased gastrointestinal motility and, less frequently, orthostatic hypotension. Clinical improvement often occurs after cessation of the drug. Muscle weakness resolves rapidly, whereas sensory symptoms may take several months to resolve. There may be residual sensory symptoms and diminished deep tendon reflexes after discontinuing the drug. Other chemotherapeutic agents that are known to cause peripheral neuropathy include platinum-based agents and taxanes.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord compression may occur in patients with spinal and/or dural metastases and manifest with sensorimotor abnormalities below the level of the lesion, and in severe cases, changes in bowel movements. However, patients typically present with hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia and develop localized, chronic back pain prior to the onset of sensorimotor abnormalities. In addition, non-Hodgkin lymphoma does not typically metastasize to the spine.

C) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes may affect any part of the nervous system and are associated with systemic cancers, usually through an antibody-mediated effect. While sensorimotor neuropathies similar to this patient's have been described, these paraneoplastic neurological syndromes are usually associated with small cell lung cancer or thymoma. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is rarely associated with paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is characterized by ascending, symmetrical muscle weakness accompanied by decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes and usually involves dysautonomia. While sensory dysesthesias may also accompany motor weakness, they are mild compared to the motor weakness. This patient's sensory symptoms are more predominant than his motor weakness. Also, dysautonomia in GBS usually involves tachycardia and hypertension/orthostasis rather than constipation. Finally, patients with GBS often complain of facial and/or oropharyngeal weakness, which is absent in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) causes mixed motor-sensory neuropathy, which is seen in this patient, CMT is hereditary and manifests in the third decade of life. Patients often have foot deformities such as pes cavus or hammer toes due to gradually increasing weakness of the lower extremity muscles. This patient has no family history of CMT, no evidence of musculoskeletal foot abnormalities, and is much older than would be expected at disease onset. Finally, CMT would not explain this patient's constipation.

F) INCORRECT:

The most common clinical manifestation of hypothyroid neuropathy is a symmetrical loss of sensation and deep tendon reflexes in the distal extremities, resulting in numbness, tingling, and painful dysesthesias, which is seen in this patient. Patients with hypothyroidism also often complain of constipation. However, weakness is rarely seen and occurs only in advanced cases. Moreover, this patient has no prior diagnosis of thyroid dysfunction and he does not have other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, cold intolerance, and fatigue).
questions.hint: This patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with bilateral peripheral neuropathy and decreased intestinal motility.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of blood in his urine, lower abdominal pain, and a burning sensation while micturating. Five months ago, he was diagnosed with high-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma and a deep vein thrombosis of his right popliteal vein. His medications include polychemotherapy every 3 weeks and a daily subcutaneous dose of low molecular weight heparin. The last cycle of chemotherapy was 2 days ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral axillary and inguinal lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and mild suprapubic tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Leukocytes
4300/mm3



Platelet count
145,000/mm3



Partial thromboplastin time
55 seconds


Prothrombin time
11 seconds (INR=1)


Urine



 RBCs
50–55/hpf


 RBC casts
negative


 WBCs
7/hpf


 Epithelial cells
5/hpf


 Bacteria
occasional


Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Protamine sulfate is used to treat heparin overdoses. This patient is receiving heparin for treatment of his deep vein thrombosis, and heparin toxicity may occasionally manifest as gross hematuria. However, instead of lower abdominal pain and dysuria, other symptoms of bleeding diathesis (e.g., epistaxis, gum bleeds, melena) would be expected with heparin overdose.

B) CORRECT:

Metabolism of cyclophosphamide gives rise to a toxic byproduct called acrolein, which is secreted in urine. Acrolein can cause hemorrhagic cystitis by destroying the bladder urothelium. Sodium 2-mercaptoethane sulfonate (mesna) prevents hemorrhagic cystitis by deactivating acrolein and by increasing the urinary excretion of cysteine, a free radical scavenger. Adequate hydration and frequent voiding are further important measures to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis.

Long-term treatment with cyclophosphamide is also associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Palifermin may be used to prevent severe oral mucositis in patients undergoing radiochemotherapy but is not indicated for prophylaxis against hemorrhagic cystitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin could have prevented a urinary tract infection (UTI), which occurs frequently among patients receiving immunosuppressant drugs. Lower UTI may manifest with lower abdominal pain, hematuria, dysuria, and bacteriuria. However, hematuria in UTIs is usually microscopic, and > 10 WBCs/hpf are typically seen. Bacteriuria in this patient is most probably the result of an unclean catch (as indicated by the presence of epithelial cells in urine).

E) INCORRECT:

Leucovorin rescue is used to prevent folic acid deficiency among patients who receive chemotherapy with antifolate agents, such as methotrexate. Intrathecal or intravenous methotrexate can be given to patients with advanced NHL to prevent or treat micrometastases in the brain. This patient, however, has cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis, which cannot be prevented by leucovorin rescue.

F) INCORRECT:

Dexrazoxane is used to prevent cardiotoxicity in patients who receive high doses of anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) or to treat skin necrosis caused by extravasation of injected anthracyclines. This patient does not have evidence of cardiotoxicity or cutaneous necrosis. Instead, he has cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis, against which dexrazoxane is ineffective. Moreover, patients with NHL receive low doses of doxorubicin, and prophylaxis with dexrazoxane would therefore be unnecessary in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone is typically used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, which frequently occurs in patients receiving doxorubicin and/or cyclophosphamide. This patient, however, has hemorrhagic cystitis, which is more effectively prevented by administering a different drug.
questions.hint: One of the most commonly used polychemotherapy regimens for high-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) is CHOP (a combination of cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisolone). Hemorrhagic cystitis, which manifests with lower urinary tract symptoms and hematuria, is a common complication of cyclophosphamide therapy.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician with his daughter because of increasing numbers of skin lesions on his scalp over the past year. He is a hobby-gardener and has not been to the physician for several years. Physical examination shows several partly confluent erythematous, scaly lesions with crusty papules on his scalp and 2 similar lesions on his forearms. The diagnosis of actinic keratosis is made and treatment with 5-fluorouracil is begun. This drug most likely acts on which of the following labeled parts of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The G0 phase is the resting phase of the cell cycle. Cell cycle independent drugs such as platinum derivates (e.g., cisplatin) and alkylating agents (e.g., busulfan, cyclophosphamide, carmustine) act on all phases of the cell cycle including the G0 phase. 5-Fluorouracil acts specifically on a different stage.

B) CORRECT:

In the S phase of the cell cycle, DNA replication occurs. Pyrimidine analogs (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, capecitabine, cytarabine), purine analogs (e.g., azathioprine, cladribine), folate analogs (e.g., methotrexate), and hydroxyurea act specifically during this stage of the cell cycle and inhibit DNA synthesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Topoisomerase inhibitors (e.g., etoposide, irinotecan) act both at the S phase and G2 phase of the cell cycle. 5-Fluorouracil does not act on both stages.

D) INCORRECT:

In the G2 phase of the cell cycle, DNA proofreading occurs in preparation for mitosis. Bleomycin, which induces breaks in the DNA via free-radical damage, acts specifically during this stage of the cell cycle. 5-Fluorouracil acts on a different stage.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the mitotic phase of the cell cycle. Drugs that inhibit microtubule activity, such as vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine, vinblastine), taxanes (e.g, paclitaxel), epothilone analogs (e.g., ixabepilone), and eribulin cause an arrest at this stage. 5-Fluorouracil acts on a different stage.
questions.hint: 5-Fluorouracil decreases the synthesis of deoxythymidine monophosphate (a nucleotide) by inhibiting thymidylate synthase.

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and progressive shortness of breath. She does not take any medications. Her pulse is 93/min and blood pressure is 112/80 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 22,000/mm3, and platelet count is 80,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows increased numbers of circulating myeloblasts. Bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. ECG, x-ray of the chest, and echocardiogram show no abnormalities. The patient is scheduled to start induction chemotherapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following long-term complications?

choices.text: Tingling sensation in a stocking-glove distribution
Decreased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon dioxide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A tingling sensation in a stocking-glove distribution indicates polyneuropathy, a common adverse effect of treatment with vinca alkaloids. These agents are also used in the treatment of leukemias. Other chemotherapeutic agents, including platinum-based agents and taxanes, also cause polyneuropathy. Polyneuropathy is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral tinnitus is a symptom of ototoxicity, which is an adverse effect of treatment with platinum-based agents. Platinum-based agents are not routinely used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. Ototoxicity is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Gross hematuria is a symptom of hemorrhagic cystitis, which is an adverse effect of treatment with cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide. These agents are also used in the treatment of leukemias. However, hemorrhagic cystitis is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon dioxide is a sign of pulmonary fibrosis, which is an adverse effect of treatment with bleomycin or busulfan. Neither agent is used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia; bleomycin is used, e.g., in the treatment of testicular cancer, ovarian cancer, and Hodgkin lymphoma, and busulfan is used in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia. Pulmonary fibrosis is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Endometrial hyperplasia is an adverse effect of treatment with tamoxifen, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). SERMs are used in the treatment of breast cancer, not acute myeloid leukemia. Endometrial hyperplasia is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

F) CORRECT:

Treatment with anthracyclines causes dose-dependent cardiotoxicity (most commonly left ventricular dysfunction or new-onset heart failure due to dilated cardiomyopathy) and requires monitoring of heart function before, during, and after treatment. Early detection of cardiotoxicity (e.g., ECG abnormalities, cardiac arrhythmias, ventricular dysfunction) is important for guiding therapy, as early manifestations are usually reversible. Cardiotoxicity can also develop after the completion of chemotherapy (sometimes years after treatment). For some patients, dexrazoxane can help prevent anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity. Other common adverse effects of anthracycline chemotherapy include myelosuppression and alopecia.

Treatment with cytarabine causes myelosuppression with megaloblastic anemia.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.
questions.hint: Chemotherapeutic agents can cause many adverse effects that warrant post-exposure monitoring. Anthracyclines (including daunorubicin) are particularly dangerous, as they can cause lasting injury to tissue during, shortly after, and long after chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with non-small cell lung cancer is enrolled in a clinical trial for a new chemotherapeutic drug. The drug prevents microtubule depolymerization by binding to the beta subunit of tubulin. The mechanism of action of this new drug is most similar to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vincristine is a mitotic inhibitor that binds to the beta subunit of tubulin and causes mitotic arrest during metaphase. However as a vinca alkaloid, compared to other mitotic inhibitors, it inhibits tubulin polymerization (preventing microtubules from assembling). This is not the same mechanism of action as the trial drug offered to the patient, which acts by inhibiting tubulin depolymerization (preventing microtubules from breaking).

B) INCORRECT:

Cladribine is an antineoplastic purine analog which inhibits DNA polymerase, leading to breakage of DNA strand and shutdown of DNA synthesis and repair, halting cell replication in the S phase. Cladribine does not act on the microtubules of the cell.

C) INCORRECT:

Etoposide is an antineoplastic topoisomerase II inhibitor that decreases DNA replication, halting cell division in the S and G2 phases. Etoposide does not act on the microtubules of the cell.

D) CORRECT:

Paclitaxel is a taxane that is used in chemotherapy regimens. It hyperstabilizes polymerized microtubules, resulting in mitotic arrest in metaphase and preventing cellular replication. Adverse effects of taxane-containing drugs include myelotoxicity and pulmonary fibrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ifosfamide is an antineoplastic oxazaphosphorine that induces DNA crosslinking at guanine, leading to impaired DNA synthesis. Ifosfamide is cell-cycle independent and does not act on the microtubules of the cell.

F) INCORRECT:

Irinotecan is an antineoplastic topoisomerase I inhibitor that prevents unwinding of DNA, leading to decreased DNA replication and halting cell replication in the S and G2 phases. Irinotecan does not act on the microtubules of the cell.

G) INCORRECT:

Bleomycin is an antibiotic that can also be used as a chemotherapeutic drug. It most likely acts through chelation of metal ions, which induces the formation of free radicals, leading to breaks in DNA and halting cell replication in the G2 phase. Bleomycin does not act on the microtubules of the cell.
questions.hint: This drug would cause a metaphase arrest during cell division.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of ringing sensation in his ear. He received this first course of neoadjuvant chemotherapy 1 week ago. Pure tone audiometry shows a sensorineural hearing loss of 45 dB. The expected beneficial effect of the drug that caused this patient's symptoms is most likely due to which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thymidine synthesis is decreased by the folic acid analogue methotrexate as well as by the pyrimidine analogues 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), capecitabine, and cytarabine. Methotrexate is used in chemotherapeutic regimens for bladder cancer but its side effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, mucositis, pulmonary fibrosis, and rarely, nephrotoxicity. Cytarabine, which is typically used to treat acute myeloid leukemias and lymphomas, causes myelosuppression and megaloblastic anemia. 5-FU and capecitabine, which are typically used for breast and gastrointestinal malignancies, are associated with myelosuppression and palmoplantar erythrodysesthesia. None of these drugs are associated with ototoxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Bortezomib and carfilzomib are proteasome inhibitors. They are used to treat multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma. Adverse effects include peripheral neuropathy and reactivation of herpes zoster (shingles). Ototoxicity is not a known side effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperstabilization of microtubules is the mechanism of action of taxanes (e.g., paclitaxel). Adverse effects of the taxane class include peripheral neuropathy, myelosuppression, interstitial pneumonitis, and alopecia. These drugs are not known to cause ototoxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Bleomycin and anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) generate free radicals. Bleomycin, which is typically used in testicular cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma, is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis and cutaneous hyperpigmentation. Anthracyclines, which are used in a wide range of non-hematological and hematological malignancies including bladder cancer, are known to cause dilated cardiomyopathy and alopecia. Neither anthracyclines nor bleomycin are known to cause ototoxicity.

E) CORRECT:

Cross-linking of DNA is the mechanism of action of platinum-based chemotherapeutic agents, such as cisplatin and carboplatin. The ototoxicity caused by these platinum-based agents is often a dose-dependent, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss (usually bilateral and irreversible), frequently accompanied by tinnitus and vertigo. Some of the other side effects of platinum-based antineoplastic drugs are nephrotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy. Nephrotoxicity can be prevented by saline diuresis and administration of amifostine.

Ototoxic antineoplastic drugs also include nitrogen mustards (e.g., cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide) and vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine, vinblastine). Other ototoxic drugs are salicylates, loop diuretics, and aminoglycosides.
questions.hint: Platinum-based chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin) are a key component of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in patients with bladder cancer. An important side effect of this class of drugs is ototoxicity.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with non-small cell lung cancer comes to the physician 4 weeks after her tumor was resected. She takes no medications. The physician starts her on a treatment regimen that includes vinblastine. This treatment puts the patient at highest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal failure is a potential adverse effect of nephrotoxic chemotherapeutic agents, such as cisplatin and carboplatin, which are also used in the treatment of certain types of lung carcinoma. It is not a common adverse effect of vinblastine.

B) INCORRECT:

The risk of pulmonary embolism may be increased by certain chemotherapeutic agents, such as tamoxifen and raloxifene. Vinblastine is not known to increase the risk of thromboembolic events.

C) INCORRECT:

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is caused by reactivation of JC virus secondary to severe immunosuppression. This condition can be induced by treatment with certain biopharmaceuticals, such as rituximab and natalizumab, but it is not a common adverse effect of vinblastine.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is a potential adverse effect of certain chemotherapeutic agents, such as bleomycin, busulfan, and methotrexate. It is not a common adverse effect of vinblastine.

E) INCORRECT:

Heart failure is a potential adverse effect of cardiotoxic chemotherapeutic agents, such as anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) and trastuzumab. It is not a common adverse effect of vinblastine.

F) CORRECT:

A major adverse effect of vinblastine is myelosuppression, which can result in leukopenia and subsequent immunosuppression. Therefore, treatment with vinblastine increases the risk of opportunistic infections, such as invasive aspergillosis. Myelosuppression is the most common dose-limiting effect of chemotherapeutic agents.

Although vincristine and vinblastine both work via the same mechanism (inhibition of microtubule polymerization), vincristine is not associated with myelosuppression. Common side effects of vincristine include constipation, paralytic ileus, and neurotoxicity.
questions.hint: Vinblastine works by inhibiting microtubule synthesis which is essential for mitosis in fast-dividing cells.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with non-Hodgkin lymphoma comes to the physician because of progressively increasing numbness and tingling in her fingers and toes. Her last cycle of chemotherapy with vincristine was 1 week ago. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch in all distal extremities. Knee and ankle deep tendon reflexes are decreased. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s peripheral neuropathy?

choices.text: Creation of free radicals that unwind DNA
Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA
Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogues into DNA

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vincristine inhibits beta-tubulin polymerization, which in turn inhibits the formation of the microtubules that are essential for cell division. While this mechanism is the basis of vincristine's antineoplastic effects, it also impairs axoplasmic transport in neurons. Peripheral neurotoxicity is a well-known adverse effect of vincristine, which can manifest with areflexia and/or distal peripheral neuropathy, as in this patient.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Creation of free radicals that cause breaks in DNA is the mechanism by which anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) target neoplastic cells. While these agents are often used in the treatment of lymphoma, peripheral neuropathy is not a common adverse effect. Typical adverse effects of anthracyclines include cardiotoxicity and myelosuppression.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) is the mechanism of action of methotrexate. Known adverse effects of methotrexate include myelosuppression (can be reversed with leucovorin supplementation), hepatotoxicity, pulmonary fibrosis, and mucositis. Vincristine does not affect folate metabolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of topoisomerase II is the mechanism of action of several classes of antineoplastic drugs, including anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin) and selective topoisomerase II inhibitors (e.g., etoposide). Common adverse effects associated with topoisomerase inhibitors include cardiotoxicity (doxorubicin) and myelosuppression (etoposide, teniposide).

E) INCORRECT:

Formation of cross-links between strands of DNA and subsequent inhibition of DNA replication is the mechanism of action of several alkylating agents (e.g., busulfan, cyclophosphamide) and platinum-based chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin). These agents can also cause peripheral neuropathy, but this patient is not receiving cisplatin or carboplatin.

F) INCORRECT:

Incorporation of false pyrimidine analogs into DNA is the mechanism of several widely used antineoplastic agents, such as 5-fluorouracil. Adverse effects of 5-FU include myelosuppression and hand-foot syndrome. However, this is not the mechanism of action of vincristine.
questions.hint: This patient with lymphoma has developed peripheral neuropathy as an adverse effect of her chemotherapy (vincristine).

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after he was diagnosed with mantle cell lymphoma. The physician recommends a chemotherapeutic regimen containing bortezomib. Which of the following best describes the effect of this drug?

choices.text: Preventing the relaxation of DNA supercoils

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Taxanes such as docetaxel and paclitaxel impair cellular replication by stabilizing the mitotic spindle, which consists of tubulin polymers, causing mitotic arrest in metaphase. They are used to treat breast cancer, ovarian cancer, gastric cancer, and prostate cancer.

B) CORRECT:

When the ubiquitin-proteasome system is inhibited by proteasome inhibitors such as bortezomib, misfolded proteins that have undergone ubiquitination are unable to be degraded in the proteasome. This leads to cell damage and death through a variety of mechanisms, including an accumulation of apoptotic proteins such as p53.

C) INCORRECT:

Alkylating agents such as cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide impair DNA replication by crosslinking DNA at the N7 site on guanine. They are used to treat leukemias, multiple myeloma, gynecological cancers, and lung cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Topoisomerase II inhibitors such as etoposide and teniposide impair the action of topoisomerase II, which relieves supercoils in DNA during replication. This inhibition leads to decreased cell replication and increased DNA damage and degradation.

E) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as erlotinib and imatinib are used to treat CML and GI stromal tumors. They inhibit specific tyrosine kinases such as the Bcr-Abl fusion protein in CML.
questions.hint: Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor.

questions.text: Several weeks after starting a new medication for rheumatoid arthritis, a 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painful ulcers in her mouth. Oral examination shows inflammation and swelling of the tongue and oropharynx and ulcers on the buccal mucosa bilaterally. Skin examination shows soft tissue swelling over her proximal interphalangeal joints and subcutaneous nodules over her elbows. Serum studies show an alanine aminotransferase level of 220 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase level of 214 U/L, and creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism of action of the drug she is taking?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) is a pyrimidine analog that inhibits thymidylate synthetase, disrupting DNA replication. It is used for the treatment of colon cancer, esophageal cancer, pancreatic cancer, but not for rheumatoid arthritis. Although the side effects of 5-FU include mucosal inflammation, it would not explain the hepatotoxicity or nephrotoxicity seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Methotrexate competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, decreasing the level of active folate (tetrahydrofolate) available for purine and deoxythymidine synthesis. This suppresses DNA synthesis and primarily affects rapidly dividing cells (e.g., cells in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, skin). Side effects of methotrexate include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, nephrotoxicity, mucosal ulcers, and pulmonary fibrosis, some of which are observed in this patient. Methotrexate is used for the treatment of leukemia, lymphoma, ectopic pregnancy, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, and rheumatoid arthritis.

Methotrexate also inhibits AICAR transformylase leading to increased intracellular concentrations of adenosine and adenine nucleotides.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil is a reversible, non-competitive inhibitor of inosine-5′-monophosphate dehydrogenase. It is used for prevention of renal transplant rejection and treatment of lupus nephritis as it is less nephrotoxic than other immunosuppressant drugs. Its adverse effects include vomiting, diarrhea, and pancytopenia. However, its side effects do not include stomatitis and hepatotoxicity, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase (both COX-1 and COX-2), decreasing the synthesis of prostaglandins and thromboxane. They have antipyretic, anti-inflammatory, and antithrombotic effects and are commonly used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects include interstitial nephritis, PUD, and renal ischemia. However, they are not known to cause stomatitis and hepatotoxicity.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids inhibit NF-κB and suppress transcription of proinflammatory cytokines. They are used for the treatment of many inflammatory and autoimmune diseases including rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects include Cushing syndrome, hyperglycemia, osteoporosis, steroid-induced leukocytosis, cataracts, and PUD. However, glucocorticoids would not explain the mucosal inflammation, hepatotoxicity, or renal toxicity seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has signs of stomatitis, hepatotoxicity, and renal toxicity, all of which are side effects of methotrexate.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman who was recently diagnosed with Crohn disease comes to the physician for evaluation of her immunosuppressive therapy. She has had recurrent flares since her diagnosis. Physical examination shows two shallow ulcers on her oral mucosa. The physician considers adding azathioprine to her medication regimen. A deficiency of which of the following enzymes would diminish the therapeutic effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Xanthine oxidase converts hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid. It also converts 6-MP into the inactive metabolite 6-thiouric acid. Deficiency of xanthine oxidase would divert 6-MP to other enzymes for metabolism, leading to increased levels of active metabolites and increased toxicity. This effect is observed when 6-MP or azathioprine are co-administered with the xanthine oxidase inhibitors allopurinol or febuxostat.

B) INCORRECT:

Thymidylate synthase converts deoxyuridine monophosphate to deoxythymidine monophosphate. This enzyme is inhibited by the chemotherapeutic agent 5-fluorouracil. It is not involved in the metabolism of 6-MP.

C) INCORRECT:

Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase converts ribose 5-phosphate into phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). PRPP is required for purine salvage and will ultimately be converted to inosine monophosphate, a process that can be inhibited by the azathioprine metabolite 6-MP. This enzyme is not involved in the metabolism of azathioprine or 6-MP.

D) CORRECT:

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) converts free purine bases (guanine and hypoxanthine) into purine nucleotides (GMP and IMP). It also converts the azathioprine metabolite 6-MP into thio-inosine monophosphate, which is the molecule directly responsible for the drug's cytotoxic effects. HGPRT deficiency would lead to a decreased conversion of 6-MP into its active metabolite, thus limiting the effectiveness of the drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Dihydrofolate reductase converts dihydrofolate into tetrahydrofolate. This enzyme is inhibited by the chemotherapeutic agent methotrexate. It is not involved in the metabolism of 6-MP.

F) INCORRECT:

Adenosine deaminase converts adenosine into inosine. This enzyme is inhibited by the chemotherapeutic agents cladribine and pentostatin, which both structurally resemble adenosine. Adenosine deaminase is not involved in the metabolism of azathioprine or its metabolite 6-MP.
questions.hint: Azathioprine is converted nonenzymatically to 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), which is subsequently metabolized into its active forms (6-thioguanine nucleotides) by an enzyme that plays an important role in the purine salvage pathway.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of lightheadedness, intermittent headaches, and easy bruising. Five months ago, she was treated for an episode of thrombophlebitis. Physical examination shows multiple bruises on her limbs. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 900,000/mm3 and elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase and uric acid. Treatment with a medication is begun that is also used in the treatment of sickle cell disease. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the beneficial effect of this drug in sickle cell disease?

choices.text: Augmentation of red blood cell production
Substitution of cofactors for DNA synthesis
Restoration of the body's iron stores

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of thrombocyte aggregation is the effect of antiplatelet agents. Aspirin, a cyclooxygenase-1 inhibitor, is used to prevent thrombotic events in essential thrombocythemia, which this patient has. However, antiplatelet agents play no role in preventing hemolysis or vaso-occlusive crises in individuals with sickle cell anemia.

B) CORRECT:

Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) does not contain β-globin chains, the mutated component in sickle cell anemia hemoglobin (HbS). Hydroxyurea increases fetal hemoglobin by altering the genetic expression of β-globin chains, with γ-globin chains being produced instead (i.e., HbF created in place of HbS or HbA). This leads to a proportional reduction in sickled hemoglobin, thus decreasing RBC polymerization (HbF does not polymerize) and sickling. Therefore, the number of hemolytic and vaso-occlusive episodes decreases.

Hydroxyurea also has a cytoreductive action, blocking DNA synthesis and cell division by inhibiting ribonucleotide reductase. This makes it a potent antimetabolite and a useful drug in the treatment of myeloproliferative diseases, as this patient has.

C) INCORRECT:

Augmentation of red blood cell production is the effect of recombinant human erythropoietin (rhEPO). This reduces the severity of anemia and need for transfusions in individuals with chronic kidney disease, chemotherapy-induced myelosuppression, and anemia of myelodysplastic syndromes. However, this patient presents with essential thrombocythemia, a myeloproliferative disease that would benefit from treatment with a cytoreductive agent (e.g., an antimetabolite), not an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent. In addition, rhEPO is not preferred in the treatment of sickle cell anemia, as it does not prevent hemolysis or vaso-occlusive crises.

D) INCORRECT:

Substitution of cofactors for DNA synthesis (i.e., Vitamin B12 and/or folic acid) is the primary treatment for megaloblastic anemia. Essential thrombocythemia, which this patient has, is caused by excessive proliferation of megakaryocytes, not ineffective DNA synthesis of erythrocyte precursors. Therefore, vitamin B12 and folic acid are not administered as therapy. In individuals with sickle cell anemia, vitamin B12 and folic acid may be supplemented to support the increased erythropoiesis following a hemolytic crisis. However, they play no role in preventing sickling of RBCs or vaso-occlusive crises.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of stem cell differentiation into megakaryocytes is the mechanism of action of IFN-α, a treatment option for essential thrombocythemia, which this patient has. However, as sickle cell anemia is a genetic mutation affecting hemoglobin, not megakaryocytes, IFN-α would not be beneficial in its management.

F) INCORRECT:

Restoration of the body's iron stores is achieved by either oral or parenteral administration of iron. Individuals with sickle cell anemia can develop iron deficiency secondary to hemolysis and urinary loss of iron. However, iron supplementation is not routinely given to adults with sickle cell anemia, as there is evidence that iron-deficient RBCs are less prone to sickling. (Iron supplementation is, however, recommended for iron-deficient children with sickle cell anemia.) This patient was diagnosed with essential thrombocythemia, a myeloproliferative disorder of platelets that is not treated with iron supplementation.

G) INCORRECT:

Drugs that prevent hemoglobin S (HbS) polymerization are still under investigation and could be the future mainstay of treatment for sickle cell disease. However, the current drug that is beneficial in treating sickle cell anemia and this patient's essential thrombocythemia does not prevent HbS polymerization.
questions.hint: Easy bruising, thrombophlebitis, and symptoms of microvascular disturbance (e.g., lightheadedness, intermittent headaches) in a patient with a dramatically elevated platelet count are suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The drug used as a cytoreductive agent in patients with ET is hydroxyurea.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive fatigue and a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows nontender cervical lymphadenopathy. Examination of a lymph node biopsy specimen confirms the diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma. The patient is started on a chemotherapy regimen with an agent that induces free radical formation, which causes DNA strand breaks. The physician informs the patient about potential adverse effects of this drug, including hyperpigmentation of the skin. The agent used in this patient most commonly leads to cell cycle arrest at which of the labeled phases?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

During the M phase of the cell cycle, the nucleus of the cell divides into two identical nuclei. Microtubule inhibitors, such as vinblastine, arrest the cell cycle at the M phase. Although vinblastine is used to treat Hodgkin lymphoma, this drug does not cause DNA strand breaks due to free radical formation or cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

B) INCORRECT:

The G1 phase of the cell cycle is a gap phase characterized by increased synthesis of RNA, proteins, and cell organelles. The cell cycle can be arrested at G1 phase or progress to either S phase or G0 phase depending on intrinsic and extrinsic signals. Inhibition of growth factors that regulate the G1 restriction point (e.g., EGFR) can arrest the cell cycle at G1 phase. Growth factor inhibitors do not cause DNA strand breaks due to free radical formation and are not used in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma. Although these drugs can cause dermatological side effects, such as rashes, hyperpigmentation of the skin is not typical.

C) INCORRECT:

The S phase of the cell cycle is characterized by protein synthesis for DNA packaging and by DNA replication. Antimetabolites, such as azathioprine and 5-fluorouracil impair DNA synthesis and arrest the cell cycle at S phase. Antimetabolites do not cause DNA strand breaks due to free radical formation, are not used for the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma, and do not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

D) INCORRECT:

The S phase of the cell cycle is characterized by protein synthesis for DNA packaging and by DNA replication. The G2 phase is a checkpoint for DNA replication errors. Topoisomerase II inhibitors, such as etoposide, cause DNA strand breaks and thereby arrest the cell cycle in the S and G2 phases. Although etoposide is used to treat Hodgkin lymphoma, this drug does not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

E) CORRECT:

The G2 phase of the cell cycle is a checkpoint for DNA replication errors. During the M phase, the nucleus of the cell divides into two identical nuclei. Bleomycin induces free radical formation, which leads to DNA strand breaks and causes cell cycle arrest at the G2 and M phases. Bleomycin is used to treat e.g., testicular cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma. Side effects of bleomycin include pulmonary toxicity (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis), hyperpigmentation of the skin, mucositis, alopecia, and minimal myelosuppression.
questions.hint: This patient most likely receives treatment with bleomycin.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with Down syndrome is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-week history of pallor, easy bruising, and progressive fatigue. He has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia that has been in remission for 2 years. Examination shows cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. Bone marrow biopsy predominantly shows immature cells that stain positive for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase. A diagnosis of relapsed acute lymphoblastic leukemia is made. Treatment with a combination chemotherapeutic regimen including teniposide is initiated. The effect of this drug is best explained by which of the following mechanisms of action?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vinca alkaloids (vincristine and vinblastine) act by inhibition of microtubule formation. By inhibiting polymerization into microtubules, they prevent mitotic spindle formation, thus arresting the cell cycle in M phase. They are not associated with breaks in DNA strands. Indications include leukemias and solid tumors. Vinblastine is also used in Hodgkin lymphoma therapy, and vincristine is used for NHL therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Antimetabolite agents, such as purine antagonists (azathioprine, 6-mercaptopurine) and pyrimidine antagonists (5-fluorouracil), act by decreasing nucleotide synthesis. By reducing the nucleotides available for DNA synthesis, they reduce cellular proliferation. They do not cause double-stranded DNA breaks. Indications include inflammatory bowel diseases, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and preventing organ rejection.

C) CORRECT:

Teniposide is likely to increase double-stranded DNA breaks through inhibition of topoisomerase II. Topoisomerase II is involved in stabilizing the intermediate form of DNA during the double-stranded break, so inhibition of the enzyme leads to permanent double-stranded breaks and then cell death. Common indications include leukemias, lymphomas, and some solid tumors (especially small cell lung carcinoma and testicular tumors). Adverse effects include alopecia and myelosuppression.

D) INCORRECT:

Bleomycin leads to free radical formation, which acts to subsequently induce breaks in DNA strands. While breaks in double-stranded DNA may be seen with bleomycin, this is not the mechanism of teniposide. Moreover, bleomycin is used in the management of lymphomas, germ cell tumors, head and neck cancers, and squamous cell carcinoma, but not in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

E) INCORRECT:

5-fluorouracil (5-FU) acts by inhibiting thymidylate synthase and thus the synthesis of thymidine, which halts DNA replication and promotes cell death. It does not cause DNA breaks. Indications include colon cancer and pancreatic cancer, and in topical form, also basal cell carcinoma and actinic keratosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Irinotecan and topotecan act by inhibition of topoisomerase I. This enzyme also causes DNA breaks but they are characteristically single-stranded. Topoisomerase I inhibitors prevent DNA reannealing after these single-stranded breaks, leading to cell death. Therefore, an increased number of double-stranded DNA breaks would not be seen. Irinotecan is used for colon cancer, and topotecan is used in small cell lung carcinoma and ovarian cancers.
questions.hint: Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) produce their bactericidal effects by the same mechanism of action.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with colorectal cancer comes to the physician for follow-up examination after undergoing a sigmoid colectomy. The physician recommends adjuvant chemotherapy with an agent that results in single-stranded DNA breaks. This chemotherapeutic agent most likely has an effect on which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Telomerase is an enzyme that is especially active during early development and adds telomeres to chromosomes to prevent their shortening during replication. Telomerases are largely inactive in mature tissues that are not undergoing replication. Many cancers, however, reactivate cellular telomerase to enable their cells to replicate chromosomes indefinitely without shortening, which makes telomerase a novel therapeutic target. However, its inhibition would result in the shortening/absence of DNA telomeres but not ssDNA breaks.

B) INCORRECT:

Topoisomerase II is an enzyme that cuts both strands of DNA to remove supercoils during DNA replication. Topoisomerase II inhibitors, such as etoposide and teniposide, form a complex with topoisomerase II and DNA that prevents proper unwinding of supercoils and reannealing of DNA during DNA replication (in the S phase). This inhibition causes dsDNA breaks but not ssDNA breaks. The accumulation of dsDNA breaks prevents proper DNA replication, transcription, and DNA repair, which induces cell cycle arrest in the late S phase or early G2 phase.

C) INCORRECT:

Apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP) endonuclease is part of the DNA base excision repair pathway that removes apurinic sites in healthy cells, but its upregulation is seen in many neoplastic processes. This enzyme is a potential pharmacologic target of chemotherapeutic agents. Inhibition would lead to DNA coding errors but not ssDNA breaks.

D) INCORRECT:

Helicase is an enzyme responsible for DNA helix unwinding in the replication process. Inhibition of this enzyme aborts the replication process because the replication enzymes cannot bind to the helical structure of DNA because they require a linear configuration. Although helicase inhibitors are not currently available as treatment options, they are being pursued as novel chemotherapeutic agents.

E) INCORRECT:

DNA polymerase III is an enzyme involved in prokaryote DNA replication, not eukaryote (human) DNA replication. There are no chemotherapies directed at this enzyme.

F) CORRECT:

Topoisomerase I is an enzyme that cuts one of the two strands of double-stranded DNA to remove supercoils during DNA replication. Its inhibition (e.g., by irinotecan or topotecan) prevents proper unwinding of supercoils and reannealing of DNA during DNA replication. This inhibition causes ssDNA breaks, which accumulate and prevent proper DNA replication, transcription, and DNA repair, which induces cell cycle arrest in the late S phase or early G2 phase.
questions.hint: A common approach in treatment of advanced stage colon carcinoma includes the adjuvant chemotherapy treatment plan FOLFIRI. One of the chemotherapeutic agents used is irinotecan, which causes ssDNA breaks by inhibiting an enzyme involved in the cell replication cycle.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of constipation, episodic bloody stools, progressive fatigue, and a 5-kg (10.2-lb) weight loss. Digital rectal examination shows a hard, 1.5-cm rectal mass. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of colorectal carcinoma. The patient begins treatment with a combination chemotherapy regimen that includes a drug that is also used in the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration. This drug most likely acts by inhibiting which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibroblast growth factor and receptor (FGF/FGFR) are tyrosine kinase signaling pathway molecules that regulate numerous processes, including embryogenesis, angiogenesis, tissue homeostasis, and wound repair. However, FGF inhibitors (e.g., lenvatinib) are not used in the treatment of advanced cancers (e.g., colorectal cancer) or in the management of age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

B) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapeutic drugs such as cetuximab, gefitinib, and erlotinib bind and block epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which inhibits cell growth in tumors that overexpress EGFR. As such, they are readily prescribed to patients with non-small cell lung cancer and colorectal cancer. However, EGFRs do not play a role in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and are therefore not targeted in its management.

C) INCORRECT:

Metalloproteinase is an enzyme that breaks down components of the extracellular matrix that are also involved in wound healing and scar formation. The role of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs) in advanced (or metastatic) cancers is currently being investigated. Despite a few promising studies, TIMPs are not currently being used in the treatment of advanced cancers like colorectal cancer, nor are they used in the management of age-related macular degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Interferon-alpha (IFN-α) is an antiviral and immunomodulatory glycoprotein obtained from human leukocytes. As a chemotherapeutic agent, IFN-α has been shown to decrease cellular proliferation and inhibit angiogenesis. IFNs have a dual role in promoting and inhibiting proliferation; studies have found them to function as both a tumor promoter and tumor suppressor in colorectal cancer (CRC). As such, giving a patient with CRC IFN-α might slow down cancer progression. However, IFN-α is not used in the management of age-related macular degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Platelet factor 4 (PF4) is produced by platelets and plays a role in both inflammation and wound healing as well as inhibition of angiogenesis. It is mainly used in treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, not advanced cancers (such as colorectal cancer) or age-related macular degeneration.

F) CORRECT:

Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a signaling molecule that stimulates de novo formation of blood vessels. Bevacizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody, is one of the most prescribed anti-VEGF medications. It is usually given in combination with cisplatin and paclitaxel, and is used as first-line or second-line therapy in many advanced (or metastatic) cancers, including colorectal cancer, advanced non-small cell lung cancer, metastatic renal cell carcinoma, and metastatic breast cancer. The overexpression of VEGF is the most likely cause of choroidal neovascularization, the leading cause of blindness in age-related macular degeneration.
questions.hint: Bevacizumab is used in the treatment of neovascular age-related macular degeneration and many advanced malignancies.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She had a mastectomy 6 months ago and received chemotherapy with doxorubicin and paclitaxel. A CT scan of the chest shows new metastases in the lungs and liver. Adjuvant therapy is initiated with a drug that inhibits the formation of deoxythymidine monophosphate and results in the accumulation of deoxyuridine triphosphate. The patient is advised to avoid folic acid supplementation while receiving this drug in order to prevent the toxic effects of this drug. Which of the following drugs was most likely given?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, which converts ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides. Hydroxyurea would, therefore, inhibit the formation of both deoxythymidine monophosphate and deoxyuridine triphosphate. Accumulation of deoxyuridine triphosphate suggests a drug that has a different mechanism of action. Also, the pharmacodynamic effects of hydroxyurea are not affected by folic acid supplementation because folate is not a cofactor of ribonucleotide reductase.

B) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is converted to 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) in vivo. 6-MP, in turn, inhibits the enzyme PRPP amidotransferase, which normally converts PRPP to 5-phosphoribosyl-1-amine. This reaction is the first step in purine synthesis. Since PRPP amidotransferase is not involved in pyrimidine synthesis, azathioprine would not inhibit the formation of deoxythymidine monophosphate, which is a pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotide. Also, the pharmacodynamic effects of azathioprine are not affected by folic acid supplementation because folate is not a cofactor of PRPP amidotransferase.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil inhibits the enzyme IMP dehydrogenase, which normally converts the purine ribonucleotide inosine monophosphate to guanosine monophosphate. Since IMP dehydrogenase is not involved in pyrimidine synthesis, mycophenolate mofetil would not inhibit the formation of deoxythymidine monophosphate, which is a pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotide. Also, the pharmacodynamic effects of mycophenolate mofetil are not affected by folic acid supplementation because folate is not a cofactor of IMP dehydrogenase.

D) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme that catalyzes the in vivo activation of folic acid to tetrahydrofolate. Tetrahydrofolate is an essential cofactor of enzyme thymidylate synthase, which converts deoxyuridine monophosphate to deoxythymidine monophosphate. Methotrexate would, therefore, inhibit the formation of deoxythymidine monophosphate and result in the accumulation of deoxyuridine triphosphate, as seen here. However, folic acid administration would decrease rather than increase the risk of methotrexate toxicity (leucovorin rescue). A different drug is associated with an increased risk of toxicity following folic acid administration.

E) CORRECT:

Capecitabine is converted to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) in vivo. 5-FU covalently binds to and inhibits the enzyme thymidylate synthase, subsequently preventing the formation of deoxythymidine monophosphate, an essential component of DNA, and increasing the concentration of its precursors, deoxyuridine monophosphate and deoxyuridine triphosphate. 5-FU can bind to thymidylate synthase only in the presence of methylene-tetrahydrofolate, which is a derivative of folic acid and a cofactor of thymidylate synthase. Therefore, the administration of folic acid concurrently with 5-FU or capecitabine augments the effects of these drugs by increasing their binding to thymidylate synthase and simultaneously increases the risk of adverse effects (e.g., myelotoxicity). In contrast, the therapeutic efficacy and the toxic effects of methotrexate are decreased by concurrent folic acid supplementation.
questions.hint: This drug is an antimetabolite that inhibits thymidylate synthase in tumor cells.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. A urine pregnancy test is positive. A pelvic ultrasound shows a normal appearing uterus with an empty intrauterine cavity and a minimal amount of free pelvic fluid. Treatment with methotrexate is begun. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A decrease in guanylate, the conjugate form of guanosine monophosphate (GMP), would be expected in patients taking mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) and ribavirin. These medications inhibit IMP dehydrogenase, which converts inosine monophosphate (IMP) to xanthosine monophosphate (which is then converted to GMP by xanthylate aminase). However, MTX inhibits pyrimidine base synthesis and would not decrease guanylate.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in thymidine monophosphate (TMP and dTMP) would not be expected in patients taking MTX. MTX competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, which catalyzes the enzymatic reaction that forms dTMP (deoxythymidine monophosphate). Thus, a patient taking methotrexate would have decreased rather than increased levels of dTMP.

C) CORRECT:

Dihydrofolate reductase reduces dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, which acts as a methyl group shuttle for thymidylate synthase. Thymidylate synthase builds thymine bases, converting deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP). Therefore, inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase by MTX results in a decreased concentration of thymine-containing deoxyribonucleosides (i.e., dTMP), which are essential precursors for DNA synthesis, and an increased concentration of dUMP. In the case of ectopic pregnancy, as seen in this patient, ineffective DNA synthesis blocks the growth and development of the fertilized egg, typically leading to a rapid decrease in β-hCG levels within one week.

Other medications that inhibit dihydrofolate reductase and therefore have similar effects to MTX include trimethoprim (an antibiotic) and pyrimethamine (an antiparasitic).

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) would not be expected in patients taking MTX. MTX competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which catalyzes the enzymatic reaction that forms dTMP (deoxythymidine monophosphate), leading to an increase in upstream precursor molecules like PRPP. PRPP would also be increased in patients taking de novo purine synthesis inhibitors (e.g., 6-mercaptopurine, azathioprine).
Image Description:

Biosynthesis of the nucleotide skeleton is an energy-intensive process that must be tightly regulated.
The key enzyme, glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase, is activated by PRPP and inhibited by ADP, ATP, GDP, and GTP.

Not shown here: High levels of ATP promote the formation of GMP, whereas high levels of GTP promote the formation of ATP. Adenylosuccinate synthetase is inhibited by AMP, and IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by GMP (negative feedback inhibition).

E) INCORRECT:

Increase in tetrahydrofolate polyglutamate, the biologically active form of folate, would not be expected in patients taking MTX. MTX competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, the enzyme responsible for activating folate. Therefore, a decrease in tetrahydrofolate polyglutamate would rather be seen in patients taking MTX.
questions.hint: Methotrexate (MTX) is the medical treatment of choice for uncomplicated ectopic pregnancy. It is an antifolate that competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent fatigue over the past ten months. His previous annual health maintenance examination showed no abnormalities. He appears pale. Physical examination shows numerous petechial lesions over the abdomen and marked splenomegaly. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.4 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4,100/mm3, and thrombocyte count is 110,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows large white blood cells with centrally placed nuclei and multiple fine, radial cytoplasmic projections that stain positively for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP). Which of the following is the most likely characteristic of the medication used as first-line treatment for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Resistant to breakdown by adenosine deaminase
Unable to cross the blood-brain barrier

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The chemotherapeutic agent tamoxifen is used to treat breast cancer and works by binding to estrogen receptors; the selective estrogen receptor modulation (due to tissue-dependent estrogenic and antiestrogenic actions) is responsible for the increased risk of thrombosis. Inhibition of estrogen receptors would not be helpful in treating this patient's hairy cell leukemia.

B) CORRECT:

Resistance to breakdown by adenosine deaminase is a hallmark of cladribine, the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia. Cladribine is a purine analog that mimics adenosine, thus inhibiting nucleotide metabolism. Resistance to degradation is crucial for its ability to inhibit lymphocytes during S phase of replication, leading to efficient destruction of rapidly dividing neoplastic cells. Pentostatin is another purine analog that is also used in the treatment of hairy cell leukemia and acts by inhibiting adenosine deaminase.

Cladribine is only activated within lymphocytes, making it highly specific for leukemic cells with minimal off-target effects. However, adverse effects can occur and include myelosuppression, neurotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapeutic agents ifosfamide and cyclophosphamide are prodrugs that require bioactivation by the liver. These are used to treat cancers such as ovarian and small cell lung cancers but not hairy cell leukemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Chemotherapeutic agents etoposide and bleomycin work by inhibiting cell cycle progression from the G2 phase. These are also used to treat various lymphomas and leukemias; however, a different agent is considered first-line for the treatment of hairy cell leukemia.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with hairy cell leukemia, for which first-line treatment is cladribine. Cladribine is able to cross the blood-brain barrier.
questions.hint: Persistent fatigue, petechial lesions, marked splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and a peripheral blood smear showing large leukocytes with fine, radial, (hair-like) cytoplasmic projections that are TRAP-positive, are all consistent with hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has a history of Crohn disease, for which she takes methotrexate. She and her husband would like to start trying to have a child. Because of the teratogenicity of methotrexate, the physician switches the patient from methotrexate to a purine analog drug that inhibits lymphocyte proliferation by blocking nucleotide synthesis. Toxicity of the newly prescribed purine analog would most likely increase if the patient was also being treated with which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Febuxostat, a noncompetitive xanthine oxidase inhibitor, increases the risk of toxicity from 6-MP. Normally, xanthine oxidase metabolizes 6-MP to inactive metabolites as well as to active compounds that account for its immunosuppressive properties. Inhibition of xanthine oxidase increases the rate at which 6-MP is converted to its active metabolites, increasing these compounds' serum levels and putting the patient at risk for toxicity. As a result, febuxostat is contraindicated in patients taking 6-MP (as well as azathioprine and theophylline, which are also metabolized to inactive substances by xanthine oxidase).

B) INCORRECT:

Pemetrexed blocks thymidylate synthase and dihydrofolate reductase, thereby preventing pyrimidine synthesis. It is not likely to increase the toxicity of the newly prescribed purine analog as it does not affect xanthine oxidase or 6-MP metabolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Rasburicase is a recombinant formulation of the enzyme urate oxidase. It helps degrade uric acid by catalyzing its conversion to a more soluble compound (allantoin) and is effective as an adjunctive measure for the prevention of tumor lysis syndrome. However, the drug does not exert a direct effect on xanthine oxidase, so it would not be expected to impair the metabolism of 6-MP. Rasburicase may, in fact, have a preventative effect against 6-MP toxicity by clearing the products of xanthine oxidase-mediated reactions and driving the equilibrium between 6-MP and its inactive metabolite towards the production of the inactive metabolite.

D) INCORRECT:

Prednisolone, a glucocorticoid, is not likely to increase the toxicity of the newly prescribed purine analog. Glucocorticoids are beneficial in acute flares of Crohn disease, but they should not be used long-term due to adverse effects. They do not interact with drugs that undergo xanthine oxidase metabolism, so they can be safely combined with 6-MP.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydroxyurea, an antimetabolite that blocks ribonucleotide reductase, prevents cells from exiting the G1/S phase of the cell cycle. It is not likely to increase the toxicity of the newly prescribed purine analog as it does not affect xanthine oxidase or 6-MP metabolism.

F) INCORRECT:

Cyclosporine would not be expected to directly increase the risk of 6-MP toxicity. Cyclosporine, a calcineurin inhibitor, is indicated in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and prevention of chronic transplant rejection. It does not interact with drugs that undergo xanthine oxidase metabolism such as 6-MP. However, calcineurin inhibitors can cause nephrotoxicity and a subsequent reduction in kidney function. Because 6-MP is eliminated renally, evidence of cyclosporine-induced nephrotoxicity should prompt redosing of 6-MP to prevent toxicity.
questions.hint: The purine analog drug in question is 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP). It undergoes enzymatic degradation by xanthine oxidase to a nontoxic metabolite.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and night sweats for 2 months. During this time, he has also had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows painless swelling of the cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. Examination of the abdomen shows hepatosplenomegaly. Histologic examination of a lymph node biopsy specimen shows Reed-Sternberg cells. A diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma is made. The patient is started on a chemotherapeutic regimen that includes bleomycin. The mechanism of action of this drug is most similar to that of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones such as ciprofloxacin are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit prokaryotic topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV. Inhibition of eukaryotic topoisomerase I or II is a mechanism of action of several antineoplastic agents (e.g., irinotecan, topotecan, etoposide, anthracyclines), but not bleomycin.

B) INCORRECT:

Griseofulvin is an antifungal that disrupts fungal mitosis by inhibiting microtubule assembly, which interferes with the formation of the mitotic spindle. It binds to keratin and therefore demonstrates good antifungal activity in keratin-containing tissues (e.g., skin and nails). Griseofulvin has a mechanism of action that is similar to the antineoplastic agents vincristine and vinblastine, but not bleomycin.
Image Description:

Polyenes bind to ergosterol in the cell membrane, creating pores that disrupt the electrolyte balance, which results in cell death.
Echinocandins inhibit the enzyme β-glucan synthase, which is essential for fungal cell wall synthesis.
Allylamine derivatives and azoles inhibit the synthesis of ergosterol, the main steroid of the fungal cell membrane.
Griseofulvin disrupts fungal mitosis by interfering with the function of microtubules.
Flucytosine, which is converted to 5-fluorouracil within the fungal nucleus, is an antimetabolite, as it inhibits the synthesis of DNA and RNA.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim (TMP) is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that inhibits bacterial dihydrofolate reductase, the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of dihydrofolic acid into active tetrahydrofolic acid. Folate derivates serve as important cofactors in the biosynthesis of both purines and pyrimidines. TMP is typically used in combination with sulfonamides (e.g., TMP-SMX) to cause a sequential block of bacterial folate synthesis. Bleomycin, however, is not an antifolate agent.
Image Description:

Sulfonamides and dapsone inhibit dihydropteroate synthase (present in bacteria). Trimethoprim and pyrimethamine inhibit the dihydrofolate reductase (present in bacteria and humans).

D) INCORRECT:

Sulfamethoxazole (SMX) is a sulfonamide antibiotic that disrupts bacterial folic acid synthesis by inhibiting dihydropteroate synthase, the enzyme that catalyzes the initial step in folic acid synthesis (PABA + pteridine → dihydropteroic acid). Folate derivates serve as important cofactors in the biosynthesis of both purines and pyrimidines. SMX is typically used in combination with trimethoprim (TMP-SMX) to cause a sequential block of bacterial folate synthesis. Bleomycin, however, is not an antifolate agent.
Image Description:

Sulfonamides and dapsone inhibit dihydropteroate synthase (present in bacteria). Trimethoprim and pyrimethamine inhibit the dihydrofolate reductase (present in bacteria and humans).

E) INCORRECT:

Rifamycins (i.e., rifampin, rifabutin) are antimycobacterial drugs that inhibit DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to prevent bacterial transcription and, by extension, protein synthesis. Inhibition of transcription is a mechanism of action of the antitumor antibiotic actinomycin D, but not bleomycin.
Image Description:

Rifamycin and streptomycin: inhibit RNA polymerase → reduction in protein synthesis
Dapsone: inhibits bacterial synthesis of dihydrofolic acid, via competition with para-aminobenzoate → reduced nucleic acid synthesis
Isoniazid: a prodrug converted into the active form isoniazid by catalase-peroxidase (KatG), which prevents cell wall synthesis via inhibition of mycolic acid production
Pyrazinamide: mechanism unknown
Ethambutol: inhibits arabinosyltransferase → prevention of mycobacterial cell wall synthesis (bacteriostatic effect)

F) CORRECT:

Metronidazole creates free radicals within bacteria and protozoa, thereby inducing DNA-strand breaks. It is a bactericidal antibiotic with good activity against anaerobes that cause infection below the diaphragm (e.g., Clostridium, Bacteroides), facultative anaerobes (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis, Helicobacter pylori), and certain protozoa (e.g., Giardia, Entamoeba, Trichomonas). In addition to bleomycin, anthracyclines such as doxorubicin and daunorubicin also induce DNA-strand breaks in eukaryotic cells by generating free radicals.
Image Description:

A. Bacterial cell envelope
- Polymyxins disrupt the outer membrane that is present in gram-negative bacteria.
- Beta-lactams, glycopeptides, and epoxides inhibit cell wall synthesis.
- Daptomycin forms ion channels on the cell membrane that lead to membrane depolarization and disruption.

B. Nucleic acids and related enzymes
- Nitroimidazoles disrupt DNA strands by creating free radicals.
- Fluoroquinolones interrupt DNA replication by inhibiting prokaryotic DNA gyrase.
- Rifamycin prevents transcription by inhibiting RNA polymerase.

C. Bacterial ribosomes
- Macrolides, amphenicols, lincosamides, and oxazolidinones inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50s subunit of the bacterial ribosome.
- Aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, and glycylcyclines inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 30s subunit of the bacterial ribosome.

D. Folic acid metabolism (required for DNA synthesis)
- Sulfamethoxazole inhibits bacterial purine synthesis by inhibiting dihydropteroate synthetase, which converts para-aminobenzoate (PABA) into dihydrofolate (DHF).
- Trimethoprim, a diaminopyrimidine, inhibits bacterial purine synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, which converts DHF into tetrahydrofolate (THF).

G) INCORRECT:

Chloramphenicol is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking peptidyltransferase at the 50S ribosomal subunit. The use of chloramphenicol is now limited due to its high toxicity. Although both bleomycin and chloramphenicol can cause bone marrow suppression, they have different mechanisms of action.
Image Description:

Schematic indicating how various antibiotics inhibit the protein synthesis activity of the bacterial ribosome by their actions during the initiation phase (left) and the elongation phase (right). Note that the details of some of these interactions vary across the literature.

Interactions at the 50S bacterial ribosome subunit:
- Oxazolidinones block the formation of the initiation complex.
- Macrolides and lincosamides primarily act by blocking translocation (solid markers) but also block the formation of the initiation complex (dotted markers indicate that this is not their main mechanism of action).
- Amphenicols block the enzyme peptidyl transferase

Interaction at the 30S bacterial ribosome subunit:
- Aminoglycosides block the formation of the initiation complex, cause codon misreading, or inhibit translocation.
- Tetracyclines and glycylcyclines block aminoacyl-tRNA from binding to the ribosome acceptor site
questions.hint: Bleomycin, an antitumor antibiotic used in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma and testicular cancer, induces the formation of free radicals that cause DNA-strand breaks (and G2 cell-cycle arrest).

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with advanced bladder cancer comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She is currently undergoing chemotherapy with an agent that forms cross-links between DNA strands. Serum studies show a creatinine concentration of 2.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen concentration of 30 mg/dL. Urine dipstick of a clean-catch midstream specimen shows 2+ protein and 1+ glucose. Prior to initiation of chemotherapy, her laboratory values were within the reference range. In addition to hydration, administration of which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mesna is a chemoprotective agent that combines with acrolein, a toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide. These chemotherapeutic agents act by creating cross-links between DNA strands and can cause proximal tubular damage, as seen in this patient. Mesna, however, helps prevent hemorrhagic cystitis, which is another known side effect of cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide, not nephrotoxicity. There is no evidence that mesna reduces the nephrotoxicity associated with cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide, and platinum-based chemotherapy.

B) CORRECT:

Administration of amifostine would most likely have helped to prevent the proximal tubular damage seen in this patient. Platinum-based chemotherapeutic agents, e.g., cisplatin, can cause selective proximal renal tubular damage through a variety of mechanisms, including inactivation of ion channel transporters and free radical generation. Amifostine is a free radical scavenger that is metabolized to an active sulfhydryl group (thiol group) donor by alkaline phosphatase. This thiol moiety combines with toxic metabolites of platinum-based drugs and reduces the risk of nephrotoxicity. Other manifestations of nephrotoxicity associated with platinum-based chemotherapy include Fanconi syndrome, hypomagnesemia, salt wasting, and anemia.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine can be used to prevent nephrotoxicity associated with contrast use in patients undergoing coronary angiography and CT scans. It is also administered as an antidote in acetaminophen poisoning in order to prevent hepatic injury. However, it would not prevent the nephrotoxicity associated with platinum-based chemotherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Dexrazoxane is a chemoprotective agent that is used to prevent the cardiotoxicity associated with anthracyclines. Anthracyclines interfere with cellular proliferation through a variety of mechanisms, including inhibition of topoisomerase II, inhibition of DNA and RNA synthesis through intercalation with DNA, DNA strand excision, and generation of free radicals. Dexrazoxane acts as a chelating agent and reduces the number of free radicals generated. It would not prevent the nephrotoxicity associated with platinum-based chemotherapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Rasburicase is a recombinant drug that metabolizes uric acid to water-soluble byproducts that can be renally excreted. It is used in the management of hyperuricemia in tumor lysis syndrome. Tumor lysis syndrome can cause acute renal failure with elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen due to acute uric acid nephropathy. However, this condition mostly occurs after initiating cytotoxic treatment of hematological malignancies and presents with further symptoms such as nausea and vomiting, lethargy, hematuria, and cardiac arrythmias. Rasburicase does not prevent the nephrotoxicity associated with platinum-based agents.

F) INCORRECT:

Leucovorin (folinic acid) is a chemoprotective agent used to decrease the toxic effects of antifolate agents such as methotrexate. Unlike the drug used in this patient, methotrexate does not act by creating cross-links between DNA strands, but competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase. Leucovorin would not prevent the nephrotoxicity associated with platinum-based chemotherapy.
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of proximal tubular damage (elevated serum creatinine and BUN, proteinuria, glycosuria), most likely due to an adverse effect of platinum-based chemotherapy, which acts by creating cross-links between DNA strands.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive back pain. He has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. His only medications are a daily multivitamin and ibuprofen, which he takes daily for the back pain. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the lower spine and the left iliac crest. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.3 g/dL, his serum calcium concentration is 12 mg/dL, and his serum creatinine concentration is 2.1 mg/dL. A bone marrow biopsy shows 21% plasma cells. A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is established. In preparation for an autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, the patient receives a myeloablative treatment regimen that includes busulfan. Which of the following drugs acts via a similar mechanism of action to busulfan?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vemurafenib is a targeted anticancer therapy that inhibits B-Raf kinase with a V600E mutation; it does not share a similar mechanism of action to busulfan, which inhibits DNA replication by creating cross-links between DNA strands.

B) INCORRECT:

Bleomycin is an antibiotic chemotherapeutic agent that inhibits DNA synthesis by fragmenting DNA strands; it does not share a similar mechanism of action to busulfan, which inhibits DNA replication by creating cross-links between DNA strands.

C) INCORRECT:

Etoposide is a chemotherapeutic agent that inhibits topoisomerase II, which leads to DNA degradation; it does not share a similar mechanism of action to busulfan, which inhibits DNA replication by creating cross-links between DNA strands.

D) CORRECT:

Lomustine is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent of the nitrosourea subgroup; similar to busulfan, it inhibits DNA replication by creating cross-links between DNA strands. These modifications cannot be repaired, which results in cell apoptosis.
