Busulfan is used as part of a conditioning regimen prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, as seen in this patient. Important adverse effects include myelosuppression, pulmonary fibrosis, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation. Lomustine is used to treat brain tumors and Hodgkin lymphoma. Important adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, and central nervous system dysfunction (e.g., ataxia, lethargy).

E) INCORRECT:

Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid chemotherapeutic agent that inhibits microtubule formation in the mitotic spindle; it does not share a similar mechanism of action to busulfan, which inhibits DNA replication by creating cross-links between DNA strands.

F) INCORRECT:

Cytarabine is a pyrimidine analog that inhibits DNA polymerase; it does not share a similar mechanism of action to busulfan, which inhibits DNA replication by creating cross-links between DNA strands.
questions.hint: Busulfan is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent of the alkyl sulfonate subgroup. It inhibits DNA replication by creating cross-links between DNA strands.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with rectal cancer comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 6 weeks after undergoing low anterior resection for the treatment of colorectal cancer. Physical examination shows a clean, nontender scar on the lower abdomen. The physician recommends an adjuvant treatment with folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil, and irinotecan. The patient is concerned about this treatment and asks about potential adverse effects. Which of the following types of cells are affected most by this therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac myocytes are permanent cells that can be damaged by 5-FU as a result of coronary vasospasm and/or the direct cardiotoxic effects of this drug. However, cardiac myocyte damage is not the most common adverse effect of 5-FU. In addition, irinotecan is not known to damage cardiac myocytes. Damage to a type of labile cell is the most likely adverse effect of combined 5-FU and irinotecan therapy. Cardiac myocyte damage is relatively more common following the use of anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) and trastuzumab.

B) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow fibroblasts are quiescent cells. 5-Fluorouracil and irinotecan are most toxic against labile cells (e.g., myeloblasts, lymphoblasts) and do not have a major effect on quiescent cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL) are quiescent cells. 5-Fluorouracil and irinotecan are most toxic against labile cells (e.g., bone marrow lymphoblasts) and do not have a major effect on quiescent cells. Glucocorticoids, certain monoclonal antibodies (e.g., rituximab), antineoplastic agents that damage or cross-link DNA (e.g., bleomycin, anthracyclines, alkylating agents), and adenosine deaminase inhibitors (e.g., cladribine, pentostatin) are toxic to PBLs because of their ability to trigger apoptosis.

D) INCORRECT:

The cells of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) are quiescent cells. PCT cells do not absorb 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), irinotecan, or their metabolites from the glomerular filtrate and would, therefore, be spared from the adverse effects of these drugs. Platinum agents (e.g., cisplatin) and alkylating agents such as ifosfamide, on the other hand, are examples of chemotherapeutic drugs that act independently of the cell cycle and can be absorbed by the PCT cells via apical transporters; these drugs can, therefore, damage PCT cells and cause nephrotoxic acute tubular necrosis and Fanconi syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Intestinal epithelial cells, hematopoietic stem cells, and gonadal germ cells are labile cells, which are those that never enter the G0 phase of the cell cycle and divide rapidly with a short G1 phase. Because of this continuous and rapid division, labile cells are affected most by chemotherapeutic drugs like 5-FU and irinotecan. Potential adverse side effects associated with the use of these drugs include diarrhea and myelosuppression. Folinic acid (leucovorin) increases both the therapeutic efficacy and the risk of adverse effects from 5-FU.
questions.hint: 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU), a thymidylate synthase inhibitor, and irinotecan, a topoisomerase I inhibitor, primarily prevent DNA replication and are, therefore, especially effective at killing rapidly dividing (labile) cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of persistent pain and swelling of her fingers. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with psoriatic arthritis. Previous treatment with ibuprofen has provided no relief. She has psoriasis treated with topical betamethasone. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows painful swelling, erythema, and limited range of motion of the distal interphalangeal joints of the third, fourth and fifth digits of the left hand and the second and third digits of the right hand. There are small round depressions in multiple nails with distal nail lifting of both index fingers. After confirming normal liver function, the patient agrees to begin low-dose methotrexate therapy. Adherence to the new medication regimen increases this patient's risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While gingival hyperplasia is an adverse effect of certain immunosuppressive agents such as cyclosporine, it is not expected under MTX therapy. Note that MTX can lead to oral mucositis manifesting with e.g., oral ulcerations.
Image Description:

Oral cavity of a patient with acute myeloid leukemia receiving chemotherapy

Whitish patches on an erythematous base are visible on the tongue and the buccal surfaces.

These inflammatory changes are characteristic of generalized oral mucositis, a possible complication of chemotherapy. These findings must be differentiated from leukoplakia or candidiasis: unlike oral mucositis, leukoplakia manifests without erythema and candidiasis with white patches that can be scraped off.

B) INCORRECT:

MTX has teratogenic effects due to folate antagonism and should therefore be discontinued prior to conception but MTX is not known to cause premature ovarian failure. This is one of the reasons why MTX is used to treat ectopic pregnancy and gestational trophoblastic disease. Premature ovarian failure is an adverse effect of certain immunosuppressive agents such as cyclophosphamide, an alkylating drug that directly damages DNA and induces follicular apoptosis.

C) CORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is a severe complication of MTX therapy that most often develops within the first year of initiating treatment. While the exact pathomechanism is unclear, MTX is thought to cause hypersensitivity interstitial pneumonitis that eventually leads to widespread fibrosis. Patients with MTX-induced pulmonary toxicity typically present with cough, dyspnea, and fever that can occur in an acute, subacute, or chronic pattern. Typical CT findings include diffuse and patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities, reticular opacities, and centrilobular nodules. Management consists of exclusion of a pulmonary infection, discontinuation of MTX therapy, and administration of glucocorticoids and supplemental oxygen for severe disease. A baseline chest x-ray prior to initiation of long-term MTX therapy is recommended to identify preexisting lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Anemia is an adverse effect of MTX therapy that patients should be monitored for. However, MTX therapy causes anemia by folate antagonism, and with high doses, by myelosuppression, and would therefore cause macrocytic or normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is caused by the reactivation of a latent JC virus in patients who are severely immunosuppressed (e.g., due to AIDS, hematologic malignancies). While some immunosuppressive drugs also increase the risk of JC virus reactivation (e.g., natalizumab), MTX is not associated with this complication. MTX-related leukoencephalopathy is a noninfectious adverse effect of intrathecal or high-dose intravenous MTX therapy.
questions.hint: This patient with psoriatic arthritis has not sufficiently responded to NSAID treatment and requires immunosuppressive therapy with a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug such as methotrexate (MTX).

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with no significant history of tobacco use presents with increasing dyspnea. She reports that she was unable to walk from her bed to the bathroom this morning without stopping to rest. She has been treated with oral erlotinib for adenocarcinoma of the lung that is widely metastatic to bone and both adrenal glands.
Her temperature is 37.1°C, her blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg, her heart rate is 112 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 21 breaths per minute. She has an oxygen saturation of 91% while breathing ambient air, but it drops to 82% as soon as she begins to walk.
She appears moderately uncomfortable. She has no jugular venous distention. On pulmonary examination, she has bilateral crackles that are especially prominent at the bases. She has no cardiac murmurs or gallops and no peripheral edema.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory testing is notable for a brain natriuretic peptide level of 8 pg/mL (reference range, ≤69), a leukocyte count of 6900 per mm3 (4500–11,000), and a D-dimer level of 0.2 μg/mL (<0.5).
Administration of adrenocorticotropic hormone increases her serum cortisol level from 14.2 μg/dL to 29.4 μg/dL. Further workup includes transthoracic echocardiography, which shows normal right and left ventricular size and function and a pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 28 mm Hg (15–25).
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s dyspnea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular heart failure would not be expected in the setting of a normal brain natriuretic peptide level.

B) INCORRECT:

The appropriate increase in this patient’s serum cortisol level following cosyntropin testing (to greater than 18 μg/dL) rules out adrenal insufficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolus is unlikely in this patient given her normal D-dimer level.

D) CORRECT:

Erlotinib and gefitinib are oral agents that inhibit the tyrosine kinase activity of epidermal growth factor receptor. Both drugs have been shown to prolong progression-free survival when compared with standard cytotoxic chemotherapy in patients with metastatic, non-small-cell lung cancers bearing epidermal growth factor receptor mutations. Erlotinib and gefitinib have also been shown to cause milder adverse effects than standard cytotoxic chemotherapy. The most common adverse effects of erlotinib are rash (75%) and diarrhea (55%). Interstitial lung disease is a rare but well-described complication of long-term therapy with erlotinib or gefitinib. This complication occurs more frequently in patients exposed to prior chemotherapy or radiation, those with preexisting lung disease, and those with lung metastases.

Key learning point: Interstitial lung disease is an uncommon but potentially fatal complication in patients receiving oral agents that inhibit the tyrosine kinase activity of epidermal growth factor receptor.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary pulmonary hypertension is unlikely in this patient given her echocardiographic findings.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman with a history of well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes notes burning paresthesias and pain in both hands and feet. The symptoms began a few weeks after she initiated albumin-bound paclitaxel for metastatic breast cancer that was diagnosed 3 months earlier.
The patient is started on hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5 mg/325 mg for pain and receives one tablet every 6 hours as needed. However, she reports no relief in her symptoms and rates her pain at 8 out of 10. Physical examination and breast examination are unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11.1
12–16


Calcium (mg/dL)
8.1
9.0–10.5


Albumin (g/dL)
2.5
3.5–5.5


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0
0.6–1.1


The remaining components of her complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are within normal limits.
Which one of the following pain management approaches would be the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Randomized trials involving patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy have failed to show benefit from monotherapy with amitriptyline.

B) INCORRECT:

A randomized trial comparing amifostine with placebo for prevention of taxane-induced neuropathy showed no difference in neurotoxicity.

C) CORRECT:

Chemotherapy agents, especially taxanes (e.g., paclitaxel), are associated with sensory neuropathies, which sometimes cause severe neuropathic pain, depending on dose and schedule.

Duloxetine, an antidepressant, is recommended by the American Society of Clinical Oncology as the first-line agent to treat chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN). This recommendation is based on the findings of a multi-institutional randomized study that showed a significantly greater decrease in mean pain score with duloxetine than with placebo. However, the observed benefit was relatively modest, and so there is some controversy about the best first-line agent. For example, the National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines recommend opioids as first-line therapy for cancer-related pain and then list antidepressants and anticonvulsants as first-line adjuvant therapies for patients with neuropathic pain. Opioids are therefore a reasonable additional choice for CIPN in patients with active malignancy, although they are considered second-line agents for chronic nonmalignant neuropathic pain according to guidelines from the International Association for the Study of Pain. Many experts favor using an opioid in the acute setting to stabilize CIPN pain and then initiating a nonopioid neuropathic agent (with the hope of being able to taper off the opioid if the patient responds to the neuropathic agent).

Key learning point: The first-line management of chemotherapy-induced neuropathic pain is duloxetine.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetyl-L-carnitine may actually worsen taxane-related neuropathy and should not be used.

E) INCORRECT:

Randomized trials involving patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy have failed to show benefit from monotherapy with gabapentin.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman who has responded well to 6 months of treatment with oral methotrexate for symptomatic rheumatoid arthritis is found to have an abnormal complete blood count and other abnormal laboratory findings. She states that she does not experience dyspnea, fatigue, or neuropathy. She drinks approximately one serving of alcohol per week.
Her vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11
12–16



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
108
80–100


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
10,000
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
180,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.6–1.1


Iron (μg/dL)
46
50–150


Total iron-binding capacity (μg/dL)
220
250–370


Ferritin (ng/mL)
200
30–300


Transferrin saturation (%)
21
15–45


What is the most likely cause of this patient’s abnormal hemogram?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency causes a prolonged prothrombin time and prolonged international normalized ratio, which can increase bleeding risk. However, the patient has no evidence of bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

The low iron level and low total iron-binding capacity in this case are likely secondary to the effects of chronic inflammation, especially considering the patient’s history of rheumatoid arthritis and elevated ferritin. Anemia of chronic inflammation, however, does not typically cause macrocytosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Myelodysplastic syndrome would typically cause macrocytosis and can be difficult to distinguish from methotrexate-induced macrocytosis. However, it unlikely in this scenario because the other lineages (leukocytes and platelets) are normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron-deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytosis rather than macrocytosis. Furthermore, the patient's iron studies do not suggest iron deficiency. In iron deficiency, there is usually a low ferritin level and an increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC). In addition, the transferrin saturation (calculated as the serum iron level divided by the serum TIBC level) is usually less than 10%; in this patient, it is 21%.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's macrocytosis is most likely due to treatment with methotrexate, which inhibits dihydrofolate reductase. Methotrexate and other drugs that inhibit DNA synthesis can cause macrocytosis.

Key learning point: A hematologic effect of treatment with methotrexate is macrocytosis.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 40 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have a cough, and it's been getting harder to breathe in the past couple weeks.”
History of Present Illness:

2-week history of progressively worsening dyspnea and nonproductive cough; dyspnea is worse with exertion
reports a new-onset rash during this period
no chest pain, fever, chills, or recent travel

Past Medical History:

2-year history of hypertension
undergoing treatment for stage II seminoma diagnosed 6 months ago

Medications:

lisinopril
bleomycin
etoposide
cisplatin

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

father: deceased at age 45 years from testicular cancer
mother: alive with no chronic conditions

Psychosocial History:
has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 24 years

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37.2 °C(98.9 °F)
102/min
26/min
130/80 mm Hg
88% on 4LNC
178 cm(5 ft 10 in)
75 kg(165 lb)
24 kg/m2




Appearance: uncomfortable; breathing with shallow, rapid respirations
Skin: linear hyperpigmented streaks with crisscross patterns on the back
Pulmonary: bilateral fine inspiratory crackles

Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppression (e.g., due to chemotherapy) increases the risk of severe varicella and disseminated zoster, which manifest with skin lesions and features of pneumonia (e.g., cough, dyspnea). However, the skin lesions appear as vesicular eruptions on an erythematous base, with a generalized distribution in varicella and dermatomal involvement in zoster.

B) CORRECT:

Bleomycin is an antitumor antibiotic used in the treatment of several malignancies (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular cancer). Important adverse effects of bleomycin include pulmonary fibrosis (due to bleomycin-induced lung injury) and flagellate hyperpigmentation of the skin. Most cases of bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis develop within weeks to months of initiating therapy, and patients often present with dyspnea, cough, and inspiratory crackles on physical examination. The cornerstone of management of bleomycin-induced lung injury is the permanent discontinuation of the drug. Other medications that can cause pulmonary fibrosis include methotrexate, nitrofurantoin, carmustine, busulfan, and amiodarone.

C) INCORRECT:

Metastatic disease involving the lungs can manifest with progressively worsening dyspnea and nonproductive cough. However, this patient's combined skin and pulmonary findings make another cause more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients undergoing chemotherapy are predisposed to bacterial infections including infection with Mycoplasma pneumoniae, which can manifest with skin lesions and symptoms of atypical pneumonia such as nonproductive cough and dyspnea. However, skin involvement in Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection typically appears as a generalized papular rash and erythema multiforme rather than hyperpigmentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiation-induced lung injury is a complication of thoracic radiotherapy and can manifest acutely as radiation pneumonitis or later as radiation-induced pulmonary fibrosis. However, radiation therapy for the testicular cancer focuses on the aortic and ipsilateral pelvic lymph nodes, and is therefore unlikely to affect the lungs.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-week history of numbness and burning sensation in his legs. He has non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Two weeks ago, he completed his last chemotherapy cycle with prednisone, vincristine, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ankle reflex is 1+ bilaterally and knee reflex is 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, vibration, and position is decreased over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vincristine is an antineoplastic drug that is used for the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Its use is limited by neurotoxicity that manifests within 4–5 weeks of initiating therapy. Vincristine usually causes a mixed symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy predominantly affecting the distal lower extremities. Early symptoms include numbness and tingling, which are accompanied by decreased deep tendon reflexes. Over time, symptoms progress to muscle weakness. Clinical improvement often occurs after cessation of the drug. Muscle weakness resolves rapidly, whereas sensory symptoms may take several months to resolve. There may be residual sensory symptoms and diminished deep tendon reflexes after discontinuing the drug. Other chemotherapeutic agents that are known to cause peripheral neuropathy include platinum-based agents and taxanes.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord compression may occur in patients with spinal and/or dural metastases and manifest with sensorimotor abnormalities below the level of the lesion. However, patients typically present with hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia and develop localized, chronic back pain prior to the onset of sensorimotor abnormalities. In addition, non-Hodgkin lymphoma does not typically metastasize to the spine.

C) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes may affect any part of the nervous system and are associated with systemic cancers, usually through an antibody-mediated effect. While sensorimotor neuropathies similar to this patient's have been described, these paraneoplastic neurological syndromes are usually associated with small cell lung cancer or thymoma. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is rarely associated with paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is characterized by ascending, symmetrical muscle weakness accompanied by decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes. While sensory dysesthesias may also accompany motor weakness, this patient does not present with the characteristic ascending muscle weakness.

E) INCORRECT:

The most common clinical manifestation of hypothyroid neuropathy is a symmetrical loss of sensation and deep tendon reflexes in the distal extremities, resulting in numbness, tingling, and painful dysesthesias, which is seen in this patient. However, this patient has no prior diagnosis of thyroid dysfunction and he does not have other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, cold intolerance, and fatigue).
questions.hint: This patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with bilateral peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of fatigue and progressive shortness of breath. She does not take any medications. Her pulse is 93/min and blood pressure is 112/80 mm Hg. Examination is normal. Her hemoglobin concentration is 80 g/L (115–155), white blood cell count is 22.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and platelet count is 80 × 109/L (130–380). A peripheral blood smear shows increased numbers of circulating myeloblasts. Bone marrow biopsy confirms a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. ECG, chest x-ray, and echocardiogram are normal. She is scheduled to start induction chemotherapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following long-term complications?

choices.text: Decreased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon dioxide.
Tingling sensation in a stocking-glove distribution.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Treatment with anthracyclines causes dose-dependent cardiotoxicity (most commonly left ventricular dysfunction or new-onset heart failure due to dilated cardiomyopathy) and requires monitoring of heart function before, during, and after treatment. Early detection of cardiotoxicity (e.g., ECG abnormalities, cardiac arrhythmias, ventricular dysfunction) is important for guiding therapy, as early manifestations are usually reversible. Cardiotoxicity can also develop after the completion of chemotherapy (sometimes years after treatment). For some patients, dexrazoxane can help prevent anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity. Other common adverse effects of anthracycline chemotherapy include myelosuppression and alopecia.

Treatment with cytarabine causes myelosuppression with megaloblastic anemia.

Key learning point: Anthracycline chemotherapy, such as daunorubicin used in acute myeloid leukemia, carries a significant risk of dose-dependent cardiotoxicity leading to left ventricular dysfunction and dilated cardiomyopathy.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon dioxide is a sign of pulmonary fibrosis, which is an adverse effect of treatment with bleomycin or busulfan. Neither agent is used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia; bleomycin is used, e.g., in the treatment of testicular cancer, ovarian cancer, and Hodgkin lymphoma, and busulfan is used in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia. Pulmonary fibrosis is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Gross hematuria is a symptom of hemorrhagic cystitis, which is an adverse effect of treatment with cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide. These agents are also used in the treatment of leukemias. However, hemorrhagic cystitis is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

A tingling sensation in a stocking-glove distribution indicates polyneuropathy, a common adverse effect of treatment with vinca alkaloids. These agents are also used in the treatment of leukemias. Other chemotherapeutic agents, including platinum-based agents and taxanes, also cause polyneuropathy. Polyneuropathy is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Bilateral tinnitus is a symptom of ototoxicity, which is an adverse effect of treatment with platinum-based agents. Platinum-based agents are not routinely used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. Ototoxicity is not a common adverse effect of cytarabine or daunorubicin therapy.
questions.hint: Chemotherapeutic agents can cause many adverse effects that warrant post-exposure monitoring. Anthracyclines (including daunorubicin) are particularly dangerous, as they can cause lasting injury to tissue during, shortly after, and long after chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-week history of numbness and burning sensation in his legs. He has a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and completed his last chemotherapy cycle with prednisone, vincristine, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin two weeks ago. Vital signs are normal. On examination, ankle reflexes are 1+ bilaterally and knee reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, vibration, and position is decreased in the lower extremities. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vincristine is an antineoplastic drug that is used for the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Its use is limited by neurotoxicity that manifests within 4–5 weeks of initiating therapy. Vincristine usually causes a mixed symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy predominantly affecting the distal lower extremities. Early symptoms include numbness and tingling, which are accompanied by decreased deep tendon reflexes. Over time, symptoms progress to muscle weakness. Clinical improvement often occurs after cessation of the drug. Muscle weakness resolves rapidly, whereas sensory symptoms may take several months to resolve. There may be residual sensory symptoms and diminished deep tendon reflexes after discontinuing the drug. Other chemotherapeutic agents that are known to cause peripheral neuropathy include platinum-based agents and taxanes.

Key learning point: Vincristine commonly causes a symmetric, distal, mixed sensory and motor peripheral neuropathy, often presenting with numbness, tingling, and decreased reflexes in the lower extremities.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes may affect any part of the nervous system and are associated with systemic cancers, usually through an antibody-mediated effect. While sensorimotor neuropathies similar to this patient's have been described, these paraneoplastic neurological syndromes are usually associated with small cell lung cancer or thymoma. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is rarely associated with paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common clinical manifestation of hypothyroid neuropathy is a symmetrical loss of sensation and deep tendon reflexes in the distal extremities, resulting in numbness, tingling, and painful dysesthesias, which is seen in this patient. However, this patient has no prior diagnosis of thyroid dysfunction and he does not have other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, cold intolerance, and fatigue).

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord compression may occur in patients with spinal and/or dural metastases and manifest with sensorimotor abnormalities below the level of the lesion. However, patients typically present with hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia and develop localized, chronic back pain prior to the onset of sensorimotor abnormalities. In addition, non-Hodgkin lymphoma does not typically metastasize to the spine.

E) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is characterized by ascending, symmetrical muscle weakness accompanied by decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes. While sensory dysesthesias may also accompany motor weakness, this patient does not present with the characteristic ascending muscle weakness.
questions.hint: This patient with non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with bilateral peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath on exertion for 5 months. She reports that she can not climb more than 2 flights of stairs and she is no longer able to run her errands as usual. One year ago, she was diagnosed with triple-negative breast cancer. She underwent a right-sided modified radical mastectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy. Cardiac examination shows a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse. Coarse inspiratory crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. The physician informs the patient that her symptoms are most likely due to an adverse effect of her chemotherapy. The drug most likely responsible for the patient's current symptoms belongs to which of the following groups of agents?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of breast cancer. This drug is associated with cardiotoxicity, which can manifest as decreased left ventricular ejection fraction and features of heart failure, as seen here. However, trastuzumab is only indicated in cases of ERBB2-positive breast cancer. Since this patient was diagnosed with triple-negative breast cancer, it is unlikely that she was treated with this drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Alkylating agents (e.g., busulfan, cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer. Adverse effects are various, but alkylating agents are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Vinca alkaloids (vincristine, vinblastine) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer and are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity. The most common adverse effects associated with vinca alkaloids are neurotoxicity (especially vincristine) and myelosuppression (especially vinblastine).

D) INCORRECT:

Antimetabolites (e.g., azathioprine, methotrexate, 5-fluorouracil) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer and are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity. The most common adverse effect associated with antimetabolites is myelotoxicity.

E) INCORRECT:

Topoisomerase I inhibitors (irinotecan, topotecan) are not typically used in the treatment of breast cancer and are unlikely to cause cardiotoxicity. The most common adverse effect associated with topoisomerase I inhibitors is myelosuppression.

F) CORRECT:

Anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin) are associated with an increased risk of developing dilated cardiomyopathy with left heart failure, which is seen in this patient. Adjuvant chemotherapy with anthracyclines is usually recommended in patients with triple-negative breast cancers because these tumors are more aggressive than other types of breast cancer and do not respond to other treatment options (e.g., hormone and targeted biologic therapy with tamoxifen and trastuzumab). Concomitant treatment with the iron-chelating agent dexrazoxane can prevent anthracycline cardiotoxicity.
Image Description:

A visual mnemonic illustrating what organ damage is associated with which chemotherapeutic agent.
questions.hint: This patient's signs and symptoms (dyspnea, laterally displaced point of maximal impulse, bilateral inspiratory crackles) and her echocardiographic findings (limited left ventricular ejection fraction) indicate left heart failure. This heart failure was most likely caused by a drug with cardiotoxic side effects that is used to treat breast cancer.
